Witness the bygone era of a pre-gunpowder society through the lens of a female protagonist, in a tale adapted from a written work to an anime series by scriptwriter Reiko Yoshida. Heike Monogatari is a dramatization of events that lead up to and during the real life Genpei War (1180-1185), whereas Saiunkoku Monogatari takes place in a fictional country that takes inspiration from Imperial China.
While only one title uses supernatural highjinks, both are takes on the all-female Takarazuka Revue.

Welcome to Demon School Ikruma-kun and Mashle are both fun comedy anime that I love and would recommend. Although the main characters are very different they along with the overall setting share similarities that I believe make each series a good recommendation. Similarities in Main Character - Mash and Iruma are both highschool aged boys that are powerless. They do not possess magic and they are just humans. Both of the go to a school full of people that can use magic and even fly while they cannot. Both characters quickly make friends and are overall kind people. They both hide their true identities because it is dangerous for others to know who they really are. Differences - Mash is a very nonchalant character and isn't too expressive while Iruma is much more fearful of his situation in the beginning. Although both characters are good people, Iruma is more inclined to help others and use kind language while Mash is more of a kuudere-esque character. He acts before he thinks and does not express much fear or anger even when he feels it. Mash has a good heart but does not go out of his way to say the kind of things that Iruma would to butter people up. Iruma is a regular human in a world of demons. He does not have his own power and much of his fear comes from that. Although Mash lives in a world full of magic users, his physical strength is incredible. Some may say he is very confident in his strength but Mash just tries to use it for everything without thinking about the consequences. The setting is similar in the way that both worlds are filled with characters that can use different kinds of magic. It is the norm to have powers and fly (with wings in Iruma-kun and a broom in Mashle). The MCs both climb the ranks at their respective schools although Mash does it for an overarching goal. Both shows are comedies and have likable characters and some good character development. I watched Mashle in sub and Welcome to Demon School in dub. I love the sub for Mashle although the dub in Iruma-kun is not the best of all the comedy anime that I have watched, it isn't Golden Time so 7/10 for me.

Both series feel familiar. They blend comedy and seriousness in a similar fashion that works really well. The cast is extremely charismatic in both cases. The story is good, you have the point of view from different opposed factions composed of likeable/agreeable characters.

They both play similarity it’s just that only the male characters opposites to each other in their own animes.

data.content: Both series has a lot more emotional and contemplational value beneath their surfaces. In both shows, the main focus of the story is our protagonist, traveling in solitude with the sole company of their mechanical companions, and in their journeys, they do encounter various parables, which rarely can be resolved with force or violence. entry.title: Honzuki no Gekokujou: Shisho ni Naru Tame ni wa Shudan wo Erandeiraremasen

data.content: While on the surface Ascendance of a Bookworm may seem like a light hearted Isekai anime about a girl that is obsessed with making books the show reveals it's self to actually be a tale of politics, greed, and corruption amongst a society of nobles as well as devotion to friends and family. This is more true of the second and third season but you need to start here. If you can look past the ingrained prejudice that you might have against Isekai and if you don't mind something a bit more light hearted and aren't committed to the idea that anime needs to be either artsy or overly edgy to be good then you might find something you like here.

Evangelion and Utena both use a plethora of references and opulent symbolism to arrive at fundamental psychological themes by way of genre deconstruction while using genre limitations to their advantage. Both stories culminate in a sort of grand cataclysm that attempts to give insight into the human condition. One could find many parallels plotwise, and given their functions in the plot there is a number of characters who are much alike one another: Anthy-Rei, Akio-Gendo, Mikage-Ritsuko, Nanami-Kaji, Touga-Misato, Utena-Shinji. This is not my novel-sized essay on the many and deep similarities between the two shows, so you'll just have to trust me on it. And Anno and Ikuhara are close friends, too. Utena is less depressive for the most part, and a bit less experimental, while it deals more with actual relationships.
It has a super good animation in addition to the story and the sound music are incredible

FLCL was a big inspiration behind Chainsaw Man, with Fujimoto even describing his hit manga as "evil FLCL" and I agree with this assessment. While they're very different in tone and story, they're both action-packed romps about deeper issues at their core. FLCL features a female character who is spunky and upbeat, as well as masking her true intentions when it comes to the male lead, and both of those features show up in CSM as well. FLCL and CSM also both follow the young male lead in his relationships with older women and examine the characters while doing so.

Both "Maison Ikkoku" and "The Girl Downstairs" are romance dramas that take place in college, the character designs are pretty similar too. -the protagonists are both male college students who have trouble expressing their romantic feelings. -the main love interests are both women with long black hair who live in the same building as the male protagonist. -the main love rival and past girlfriend of the protagonist are women with short brown hair. -there's also a girl w/ red hair who lives in same building with the others and also acts as a love rival, although Akemi in "Maison Ikkoku" is more for comic relief. -in addition alcohol is a big plot device in both, with characters frequently partying and getting drunk, then saying/doing stupid things that progress the story. There are plenty of differences of course, the main being that "The Girl Downstairs" is currently airing right now (Spring 2023) while "Maison Ikkoku" came out more than 37 years ago. All said though, they both give off the same kind of vibe.
both are shounen that focus on someone that is very good at a specific skill and instead of the MC having physical battles, they have battles on that skill. The humor elements are also similar.

Both are centered around how women are viewed as mere objects of desire and how they are punished for just existing within the confines of the patriarchy. Equally as strong in it's feminist message but even more subverted since it uses it's pornographic content against the viewer to ask some profound questions.

- Both shows feature the MC who is unlucky in their lives: Izumi's clumsiness and Shiraishi being invisible to everyone else except for Kubo herself. - Both shows feature a cute and caring girlfriend developing a healthy relationship with their MC. They are also popular in the class (or school to be fair). - Both shows don't have any drama so it's easy to get invested in fluffy romcoms as such.

Similarities: - Both are produced by Production I.G. - Both's artstyle is mainly similar moreover Shogo Makishima and William Moriarty's character designs. - Both are mystery thrillers focusing on conflict with a hero and villain. - In the beginning of both series, they do have a main plot but start episodically and focus on main plot later on. - Both's main characters are devious geniuses who seem like villains-for-no-reason in the beginning of show. - Both series are famous among young female and male anime fans because of charismatic and cold characters, respectively. - Both heroes smoke (Shinya Kogami and Sherlock Holmes). Differences: - Polar opposite settings, MTP is set around 1879, England and Psycho-Pass is set around 2113, in Japan. - MTP is adapted from manga, Psycho-Pass is original. - MTP is shonen, while Psycho-Pass being original does not have a confirmed demography but is mostly considered as seinen in fans. - MTP is not as realistic as Psycho-Pass, doesn't mean MTP is any less interesting. - MTP can be enjoyed more if you like characters but don't care about story, while its completely other way around Psycho-Pass. - Psycho-Pass heavily relies on Sci-Fi elements to move the story. - William is anti-hero and Shogo is anti-villian.

They are close in concept where someone gets introduced to a society that hides their true goal and gets instructed to carry out jobs if they don't want to become useless/be considered traitors, sometimes said jobs aren't even adequate for the level of skill our characters have. As well as having this feeling of dread as we know many characters may die in any second and expecting our main character to exceed their limits once more. Demons in CSM act similar to the Yoma from Claymore in the sense that both differ from your redemptive villains as they just outright look at humans as inferior beings (as well as hiding their true form or potential), making them the perfect threat for us to sympathize with the people affected by them and cheer for the "heroes" even if some are shown to have not the best of intentions with them using the power of their enemies against them (contracts for CSM, Yoma energy for Claymore). I'd say they both contain gore and horror aspects that make it worth checking one or the other after watching either of them first especially if you like grittier and more mature themes with twists and turns.

The significant similarity between both is the difficult decisions made by creators (in this case, Gene a newbie director, and the Ashirogi Muto manga duo) to make a better product and consistent vision. I won't get into detail further than its synopses but for Gene acquiring his first directorial credit is a hard task as he has to work against a deadline and a heavy amount of workload unless he delays the project which could trample over the production, same with Bakuman. where the artist/author duo have to adjust to a weekly schedule to get the story, paneling, and art sorted out just to be thrown into another labor-filled week beset with the underlying dread of getting their series canceled, that is if they even make it as far as a one-shot story published in the magazine. Both have what you'd consider rivals but they're mostly sources of inspiration for the main characters as they are genius in their respective industries. For Pompo: The Cinéphile, well, who else but Pompo herself! A director who apparently only shoots B-grade flicks but created a magnificent script that she hands over for Gene to adapt. For Bakuman. there's Eiji Niizuma, a gifted mangaka that has no problems with his deadlines, almost like the story and art come naturally to him, and rises to the top ranking of the magazine. Still, remember they both have a somewhat idealized look at their corresponding industries even if they can be harsh and demonstrate the tense environment creators live in sometimes characters will do specific things that should create a massive stir-up with their peers and audience, that you can't visualize their superiors/higher-ups letting slide, yet get away with (albeit not unscathed mind you). I'd say Bakuman. is far more realistic with the kind of penalty you'd get if you pull a risky decision and ends up getting a fitting development all the way through (s1-3) while Pompo hastens over to a specific point by its ending.
-Annoying characters causing mayhem for themselves -Both have a normal character that is amongst idiots -Catchy OP

Seeing how they overcome different difficulties on their path to fulfill their dreams and fall in love is very heartwarming. - Protagonist that has very good knowledge in their respective field, but still have a space to grow - 1000+ year magical companion love interest - Apples - Traveling around the contry, quite fast time progression - Interesting world, with economy that impacts the story and main character job

entry.title: Boku no Kokoro no Yabai Yatsu

data.content: Both by Shin-Ei Animations, they took what they did with Takagi-san and improved on it. Both are wholesome slice of life romance shows that will make your heart skip.

Both Arrietty and Hakumei to mikochi follow the lives of very tiny humans. Both have a comparable atmosphere, where the tiny humans use food and objects that are huge for them and small for normal humans. Both are also comparable in the generally relaxing pace and little conflict. Both are a recomendation if you're looking for a cute anime about small people and cozyness.
Similar 1980s anime with light-hearted action/adventure set in the future.
Essentially Immortal white-haired protagonist who gets good character development over the series, both are fantasy with great character writing.

Both have lot's of moe moments. Strong individual female character with her own job and duties. And a strong, noble, bit cheeky male character, leading the relationship. Yet Akagami is less misogynistic and no main tsundere, which is a plus. Definitely worth a watch.

lol this is super obvious form the beginning in both the animes 1. guy meets a girl that is very cheerful 2. girl makes the guy more extroverted by being his friend 3. both guy look super similar lol specs, nerds, same hairstyle, introverted but passionate 4. medical conditions issue (lmao) 5. OP and ending sound pretty similar (same vibes of acoustic instruments)

Both guys enter under extremely unique conditions, having a magic-related tsundere girl companion, having their own harem, but the strength point is quite different. However, Zero did a brilliant job of character development.
